title: Democrats Labor to Stem Flow of Union Voters to Trump
text:
Like many in Virginia, Minn., Jim Pechonick works at an iron ore mine and was raised a Democrat. Then came Donald Trump with promises to restore the greatness of American steel.

“The only time in my life I’ve ever been out of a job was under Obama,” said Mr. Pechonick, 51 years old, recalling a stretch in 2009-10 when the mine closed due to the poor economy. In 2016, he joined a sizable number of union workers, particularly white men, who voted for Mr. Trump. “Somebody needed to shake up the country,” he said.

The shift helped Mr. Trump win Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan, states with strong union traditions, and has put Minnesota—which he lost narrowly three years ago—into possible contention in 2020. The president’s appeal to builders, electricians, plumbers, roofers and miners has alarmed labor leaders, who are now scrambling to prevent further erosion.

“It’s a serious problem for us,” said Alan Netland, president of the North East Area Labor Council in Duluth, Minn., which represents 40,000 union members. “People may say, ‘I voted Republican and the world didn’t fall in, so maybe I better keep doing that.’”

Union officials, along with Democratic presidential candidates, are now trying to highlight what they see as a yawning gap between the president’s pro-worker rhetoric and his policies.

Mr. Trump’s campaign points to the strong economy and steps he has taken to protect American jobs, including tearing up global trade deals, levying tariffs on foreign steel and clearing away environmental obstacles for mining and other industries. It plans to launch a grass-roots labor coalition in which pro-Trump union members would seek to recruit fellow workers to support the president.

Mr. Trump as a candidate sold himself as a friend to labor, blasting the North American Free Trade Agreement and pressing an “America First” agenda focused on returning manufacturing jobs lost to Mexico and China.

As a result, Mr. Trump did better among union members than any Republican since Ronald Reagan.

While Hillary Clinton commanded the overall labor vote partly due to strength among public sector unions, which account for nearly half of union members, her numbers were down about 10 percentage points from President Barack Obama ’s in 2012. Mr. Trump’s stance on immigration and guns resonated with those voters and now, his campaign is counting on an increasingly liberal Democratic Party to turn off more.

“They’ve gone so far left,” said Mr. Pechonick, who was having a beer at the Sawmill Saloon, a hangout for miners, said of Democrats. Still, Mr. Pechonick is waiting to see which Democratic candidate emerges, noting he felt the tax bill the president signed into law favored the wealthy.

Union leaders and Democrats see an opening. Mr. Trump, they point out, hasn’t delivered on his promise to push a massive job-creating infrastructure package and his administration has scaled back overtime and other worker protections. Last week, the president nominated Eugene Scalia, a former corporate lawyer who has battled unions, to be the next Labor Department secretary.

Democratic candidates have put appeals to working-class voters at the front of their campaigns. “I am a union man,” declared former Vice President Joe Biden, who leads in 2020 primary polls, during his campaign kickoff in Pennsylvania in May.

The president was paying attention. He unleashed a wave of tweets as Mr. Biden collected an endorsement from the national firefighters’ union. “I’ve done more for Firefighters than this dues sucking union will ever do, and I get paid ZERO!” Mr. Trump wrote. During a recent speech at a petrochemical plant in Pennsylvania, he urged rank-and-file union members to take action against leaders who continue to press them to back Democrats. “Vote them the hell out of office,” he said.

Jim Pechonick, 51, voted for Donald Trump in 2016, reflecting the trend among Northern Minnesota union members moving away from the Democratic Party. Photo: Alex Leary/The Wall Street Journal

Joseph McCartin, a labor expert at Georgetown University, said 2016 wasn’t just about Mr. Trump pulling in significant amounts of union support in Midwestern states; it was a reflection on the decline of organized labor. Wisconsin, which Mr. Trump won by about 23,000 votes, lost 176,000 union members from 2008-2016, according to his research. The trend was similar in Pennsylvania and Michigan.

Union membership has declined nationally for decades as manufacturing jobs waned and outsourcing grew, in addition to other factors.

The concern seen in Minnesota was apparent in Erie County, Pa., a blue-collar stronghold since the 1980s that was one of several counties in the state that flipped for Mr. Trump. “He won the presidency here. I am determined to change that,” said Bill McLaughlin, business manager of the local chapter of the Laborers’ International Union of North America.

On a recent day, Mr. McLaughlin talked to three laborers in bright yellow shirts smoking on their break at a construction site. Two men said they had voted for Mrs. Clinton, and the third said he didn’t vote. Mr. McLaughlin started his pitch anyway. He said if a rule change to apprenticeship programs proposed by the U.S. Labor Department goes through, union laborers in Erie could see their wages and benefits cut to $17 an hour from more than $40 an hour. “I hope you have some very strong feelings about the election,” he said.

Across the city, Scott Johnson, business manager of Local 210 of the United Union of Roofers, Waterproofers and Allied Workers, said he thinks about 50% of the local supports the president. Mr. Johnson said he finds many of Mr. Trump’s tweets offensive and thinks the president gets too much credit for the economy. “It’s hard to get any of the members that are for him to even see that that’s not even 100% the case, but they’ll say Obama tanked the economy and killed the jobs,” he said.

Working a few feet away in the same office at the union hall was Ted Lunger, who worked for 15 years as a roofer and is a huge Trump supporter. He said he likes the president’s stands on immigration and the Second Amendment and finds the tweets and spats with Democrats entertaining. More than half the members of the union would vote for Mr. Trump, he predicted. “I just think he’s good for the economy.”

Steve Bonach, president of the United Steelworkers Local Union 1938 in Virginia, Minn., says a lot of the union members backed Donald Trump in 2016 despite longstanding Democratic allegiance. Photo: Alex Leary/The Wall Street Journal

There are 720,000 union members in Pennsylvania, and Mr. Trump won the state by just 44,000 votes. Rick Bloomingdale, president of the state federation of the AFL-CIO, said the president will hold on to socially conservative members concerned about abortion and gun rights. “We just have to convince 44,000 or 30,000 people that voted for Trump last time to vote for someone else.”

Some union members who backed the president in 2016 are rethinking their votes, Mr. Bloomingdale said. “In some areas where Trump did well there’s been some disillusionment, but not totally. They’re not convinced the Democrats are there yet either. They’re waiting to hear what the candidates are going to say about the economy.”

Democrats have made that a central focus of their campaign, pressing that they aren’t taking union votes for granted. Many candidates, including Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg, have joined workers on the picket lines.

Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont released a plan last month intended to double union membership and he, and others, tweaked his Medicare for All plan based on concerns from some union members that a government plan would be less generous than their union benefits.

Some officials with industrial unions say they’re dissatisfied with Mr. Trump’s challengers so far. “It’s going to be tough to get our members to vote for a Democrat,” said Chuck Knissel, a vice president with the United Mine Workers of America in Uniontown, Pa., 45 miles south of Pittsburgh.

Mr. Knissel, a Democrat who said he doesn’t support Mr. Trump, said he wanted to throw up watching a recent Democratic debate as candidates all said they want to end the use of coal. He credits Mr. Trump with successfully targeting working class voters. “What he did to get elected was genius,” said Mr. Knissel.

“He took the working-class people out of the Democratic Party.”

—Eliza Collins contributed to this article.

Write to Alex Leary at alex.leary@wsj.com and Kris Maher at kris.maher@wsj.com
description: President Trump won in 2016 in part by peeling off rank-and-file union members. Now Democrats hope to lure them back.
